question:
Of the eight students—George, Helen, Irving, Kyle, Lenore, Nina, Olivia, and Robert—in a seminar, exactly six will give individual oral reports during three consecutive days—Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday. Exactly two reports will be given each day—one in the morning and one in the afternoon—according to the following conditions: Tuesday is the only day on which George can give a report. Neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report. If Nina gives a report, then on the next day Helen and Irving must both give reports, unless Nina's report is given on Wednesday.

Which one of the following could be the schedule of the students' reports?
A) Mon. morning: Helen; Mon. afternoon: Robert Tues. morning: Olivia; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Lenore; Wed. afternoon: Kyle
B) Mon. morning: Irving; Mon. afternoon: Olivia Tues. morning: Helen; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Nina; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
C) Mon. morning: Lenore; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: George; Tues. afternoon: Kyle Wed. morning: Robert; Wed. afternoon: Irving
D) Mon. morning: Nina; Mon. afternoon: Helen Tues. morning: Robert; Tues. afternoon: Irving Wed. morning: Olivia; Wed. afternoon: Lenore
E) Mon. morning: Olivia; Mon. afternoon: Nina Tues. morning: Irving; Tues. afternoon: Helen Wed. morning: Kyle; Wed. afternoon: George
chain_of_thought: George can only give a report on Tuesday. Nina's report can trigger Helen and Irving to give reports the next day. Since there are only two reports per day, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report, we can eliminate options that have Olivia or Robert giving an afternoon report. We can also eliminate options that have George giving a report on a day other than Tuesday. In A, Olivia is giving a report on Tuesday afternoon, which is invalid. In B, Nina is giving a report on Wednesday, but there is no indication that Helen and Irving must give reports on Thursday. In C, George is giving a report on Tuesday, which is valid. In D, Robert is giving a report on Tuesday afternoon, which is invalid. In E, Nina is giving a report on Tuesday, which would trigger Helen and Irving to give reports on Wednesday, so this option is also invalid. Therefore, only C could be the schedule.
full_output:
<think>George can only give a report on Tuesday. Nina's report can trigger Helen and Irving to give reports the next day. Since there are only two reports per day, and neither Olivia nor Robert can give an afternoon report, we can eliminate options that have Olivia or Robert giving an afternoon report. We can also eliminate options that have George giving a report on a day other than Tuesday. In A, Olivia is giving a report on Tuesday afternoon, which is invalid. In B, Nina is giving a report on Wednesday, but there is no indication that Helen and Irving must give reports on Thursday. In C, George is giving a report on Tuesday, which is valid. In D, Robert is giving a report on Tuesday afternoon, which is invalid. In E, Nina is giving a report on Tuesday, which would trigger Helen and Irving to give reports on Wednesday, so this option is also invalid. Therefore, only C could be the schedule.</think>
<ans>C</ans>

Option A violates the rule that at least three novels are selected (only one novel). Option C violates the rule that at least three but no more than four novels are selected (only two novels). Therefore, only D satisfies all conditions.
full_output:

Option E violates the limit of four French works (three French novels and two French plays), so we can eliminate E. Option A violates the rule that at least three novels are selected (only one novel). Option C violates the rule that at least three but no more than four novels are selected (only two novels). Therefore, only D satisfies all conditions.</think>
<ans>D</ans>

Now we need to check if at least one composition is performed either after O and before S, or after S and before O.
